document.docAuthor: França, Diogo, Paprocki, Henrique & Calor, Adolfo R.
document.masterDocTitle: The genus Macrostemum Kolenati 1859 (Trichoptera: Hydropsychidae) in the Neotropical Region: Description of two new species, taxonomic notes, distributional records and key to males

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Macrostemum Kolenati 1859 (Trichoptera: Hydropsychidae) in the Neotropical Region: Description of two new species, taxonomic notes, distributional records and key to males

subSubSection.paragraph:
Hydropsyche hyalina Pictet, F.J. 1836 : 402
, Plate [ type locality: Indes Orientales; type lost (Hollier 2007 ); sex unknown]
Macronema hyalinum (F.J. Pictet)
; Burmeister 1839 : 916 [ type locality; distribution]; Ulmer 1905 b: 67, 68, 69 , Plate 2 [wings; ♂]; Ulmer 1907 a: 75, 76, Plate 3 [♂; wings]; Fischer 1963 : 188 [bibliography, distribution]; Flint 1978 : 389, 413, 416 [distribution, ♂, wings]

Macrostemum hyalinum (F.J. Pictet)
; Flint 1996 : 412 [distribution]; Flint et al. 1999 : 68 [taxonomic notes; distribution]; Marinoni & Almeida 2000 : 286 [distribution]; Paprocki et al. 2004 : 8 [distribution]; Hollier 2007 : 53 [ holotype situation]; Dumas et al. 2009 : 358 [distribution]; Calor 2011 : 321 [distribution]; Nogueira & Cabette 2011 : 351 [distribution].

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
Macrostemum hyalinum
(F.J. Pictet 1836)
, male genitalia. A and B, variants, left lateral view; C, phallus, left lateral view; D, apex of phallus, ventral view; E, terga IX and X, dorsal view.

FIGURE 11.
Macrostemum hyalinum
(F.J. Pictet 1836)
, right fore- and hind wings, dorsal view. A–D, variants.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Macrostemum hyalinum
can be diagnosed by the two longitudinal rows of setae near the medial region of abdominal segment X. Abdominal segment X varies from acuminate to truncate in lateral view. The phallotremal sclerite resembles that of
Macrostemum digramma
but does not have a pair of dorsal processes. The color pattern of the forewings is variable, each with the apical spot extending to the edge of the wing.

Synopsis . Adults pinned. Forewing mean length 9.9 mm ( 8.88–11.37 mm , n= 63 ). Head with small medial carina, sometimes entirely black, sometimes black with yellow spots on genal region and warts or brown on dorsal and yellow on genal surfaces. Compound eyes brown. Scapes black, brown or yellow with ferruginous and golden setae. Maxillary palps entirely brown, yellow, or with both colors, covered by ferruginous and golden setae. Prothorax entire black or with brownish-yellow spot on each pleural surface. Meso- and metathorax black, brown or with both colors. Legs brownish-yellow. Tibial spur formula 2,4, 4 . Forewings dark, with hyaline marks, each with three distinct spots beginning near middle of posterior margin and extending toward apical area; apical spot sometimes extending around apical area; discoidal cell present; radial sector markedly expanded (
Figs. 11
A–D).

Male genitalia. Abdominal segment IX, in lateral view, with anterior and posterior margins sinuous; posterior margin deeply notched, bordered by long setae above and below notch (
Fig. 10
A–B); in dorsal view, with posterior margin bearing medial acuminate keel and long setae bordering right and left margins (
Fig. 10
E). Segment X, in dorsal view, bilobed, each lobe apically rounded and with subapical wart (
Fig. 10
E); in lateral view, ovoid to subtriangular, apically rounded or acuminate, with two longitudinal rows of short, subdorsal setae near mid-length (
Figs. 10
A–B). Inferior appendages uniformly wide, each covered by small setae throughout its length, except with longer setae on dorsal surface; basal segment two to three times length of apical segment; apical segment straight and slightly clavate (
Figs 10
A–B). Phallus arched; apex, in lateral view, subtruncate apically (
Fig. 10
C); phallotremal sclerite without dorsal processes, bearing anterior margin concave and posterior margin with pair of large, rounded prominences (
Fig. 10
D); phallotrema rounded, concave, apically positioned on posterior surface of phallus (
Fig. 10
D).

Remarks . The type series of
M. hyalinum
was lost (Hollier 2007 ) and the type locality may have been wrongly described. According to F.J. Pictet ( 1836 ) this species is from “Indes orientales” but several authors (Burmeister 1839 ; Ulmer 1905 b, 1907 a, 1913 ) have reported this species from Brazil . Burmeister ( 1839 ) argued that Brazil is the type locality of
M. hyalinum
, even though F.J. Pictet described it from the East Indies. In addition, Ulmer ( 1905 b, 1907 a, 1913 ) indicated that Brazil is the locality of
M. hyalinum
. We did not find any work that collected
M. hyalinum
in the East Indies or that mentioned this place as the type locality. Thus, we state that
M. hyalinum
is found only in South America .
Distribution. Brazil ( AC , BA , CE , ES , MT, PA, PB , PE , PR, RJ, SP), Colombia , Guyana , Peru and Venezuela .
